articles.headline: Biden Seeks to Use Infrastructure Plan to Address Racial Inequities
articles.snippet: The president’s $2 trillion proposal allocates money to help communities of color, like a New Orleans neighborhood devastated by a highway project a half-century ago.
articles.abstract: The president’s $2 trillion proposal allocates money to help communities of color, like a New Orleans neighborhood devastated by a highway project a half-century ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — America’s most celebrated infrastructure initiative, the interstate highway system, rammed an elevated freeway through the center of Claiborne Avenue in New Orleans in the late 1960s.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Zolan Kanno-Youngs

articles.headline: Justice Dept. Inquiry Into Matt Gaetz Said to Be Focused on Cash Paid to Women
articles.snippet: The congressman and a former official in Florida sent money to the women using cash apps, receipts showed.
articles.abstract: The congressman and a former official in Florida sent money to the women using cash apps, receipts showed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A Justice Department investigation into Representative Matt Gaetz and an indicted Florida politician is focusing on their involvement with multiple women who were recruited online for sex and received cash payments, according to people close to the investigation and text messages and payment receipts reviewed by The New York Times.
articles.byline: By Katie Benner and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Strong U.S. Job Growth in March Fuels Optimism on Recovery
articles.snippet: The gain of 916,000 was the biggest since August, and unemployment fell to 6 percent. Barring a setback in fighting the virus, the outlook is bullish.
articles.abstract: The gain of 916,000 was the biggest since August, and unemployment fell to 6 percent. Barring a setback in fighting the virus, the outlook is bullish.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American job market roared back to life in March — and with vaccinations accelerating, businesses reopening and federal aid flowing, the rebound should only get stronger from here.

articles.headline: The Ghosts of Brooks Brothers
articles.snippet: After the retailer filed for bankruptcy one couple was left with a warehouse full of abandoned mannequins and a hefty price tag to dispose of it.
articles.abstract: After the retailer filed for bankruptcy one couple was left with a warehouse full of abandoned mannequins and a hefty price tag to dispose of it.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Sapna Maheshwari and Vanessa Friedman

articles.headline: ‘Mommy, I Have Bad News’: For Young Migrants, Mexico Can Be the End of the Road
articles.snippet: Thousands of young migrants, most from Central America, are making their way to the border, many hoping to meet parents in the United States. But for those caught in Mexico, there is only near-certain deportation.
articles.abstract: Thousands of young migrants, most from Central America, are making their way to the border, many hoping to meet parents in the United States. But for those caught in Mexico, there is only near-certain deportation.
articles.lead_paragraph: CIUDAD JUÁREZ, Mexico — The children tumbled out of a white van, dazed and tired, rubbing sleep from their eyes.
articles.byline: By Maria Abi-Habib and Daniel Berehulak

articles.headline: No Federal Taxes for Dozens of Big, Profitable Companies
articles.snippet: FedEx and Nike are among those found to have avoided U.S. tax liability for three straight years.
articles.abstract: FedEx and Nike are among those found to have avoided U.S. tax liability for three straight years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just as the Biden administration is pushing to raise taxes on corporations, a new study finds that at least 55 of America’s largest paid no taxes last year on billions of dollars in profits.

articles.headline: Returning to the Office Sparks Anxiety and Dread for Some
articles.snippet: After a year of working remotely, some employees are not keen to go back to the office, and, so far, employers are being receptive to their concerns.
articles.abstract: After a year of working remotely, some employees are not keen to go back to the office, and, so far, employers are being receptive to their concerns.
articles.lead_paragraph: A year after the pandemic abruptly forced tens of millions of people to start working from home, disrupting family lives and derailing careers, employers are now getting ready to bring workers back to offices. But for some people the prospect of returning to their desks is provoking anxiety, dread and even panic, rather than relief.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: A Chinese ‘Auntie’ Went on a Solo Road Trip. Now, She’s a Feminist Icon.
articles.snippet: Tired of housework and an unhappy marriage, a 56-year-old woman has been on a six-month jaunt across China that has challenged deep-rooted gender norms.
articles.abstract: Tired of housework and an unhappy marriage, a 56-year-old woman has been on a six-month jaunt across China that has challenged deep-rooted gender norms.
articles.lead_paragraph: She spends each night alone, curled up in a four-and-a-half by eight-foot rooftop tent, balanced on stilts above her car. She often eats her meals in parking lots. She has seen her daughter and grandchildren only once in the past six months, and her husband not at all.
articles.byline: By Joy Dong and Vivian Wang

articles.headline: America’s Record-Setting Stimulus Could Power a Rebound in Other Countries
articles.snippet: As Americans buy more, they are expected to spur trade and investment and invigorate demand for German cars, Australian wine, Mexican auto parts and French fashions.
articles.abstract: As Americans buy more, they are expected to spur trade and investment and invigorate demand for German cars, Australian wine, Mexican auto parts and French fashions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Washington’s robust spending in response to the coronavirus crisis is helping to pull the United States out of its sharpest economic slump in decades, funneling trillions of dollars to Americans’ checking accounts and to businesses.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Jack Ewing
